label: Charleston's Historic Houses, 1952:  Fifth Annual Tours Sponsored by Historic Charleston Foundation
description: Descriptions and photographs of the historic houses on tour in 1952.  Published by Historic Charleston Foundation, 1952; printed by Walker, Evans & Cogswell.  Sixty pages.  (Note:  All a/k/a references pertain to the name of the house as listed in Jonathan Poston's book The Buildings of Charleston:  A Guide to the City's Architecture; USC Press, 1997.)

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: WILLIAM RHETT'S HOUSE THOMAS ROSE'S HOUSE JOSEPH WINTHROP'S HOUSE TOURS OF CHARLESTON'S HISTORIC HOUSES Schedule for 1952, March 16 to April 12 SPONSORED BY HISTORIC CHARLESTON FOUNDATION Headquarters, 94 Church Street, Charleston, S. C. Telephone 3-1168 Special Evening Tours on Tuesdays and Thursdays. TOUR A Sunday, March 16'2 p.m. to 6 p.m. 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., March 17, IS, 19, 20, 21. 10 a.m. to 1p.m., March 24, 25, 26, 27, 28. WILLIAM HENDRICKS' BUILDINGS, 83 Church Street, e. 1749. A charming bit of imaginative restoration, typical of much that has been done in Charleston recently. Built soon after fire of 1740 by William Hendricks, planter of Christ Church Parish. Restored in 1936 by Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds D. Brown. THOMAS ROSE'S HOUSE, 59 Church Street, c. 1735. Very handsome early Georgian house. Said to be haunted, and by a young poet who died from a duel over an actress. Home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry P. Staats. Retains its original panelling, and is furnished with a fine collection of Adam, Chippendale and Hepplewhite. YOUNG-JOHNSON HOUSE, 35 Church Street, c. 1770. Characteristic "single" house, built before Revolution. Home of Wilmer Hoffman, well-known sculptor, who restored it and filled it with notable collection of family furniture and objects of art, ably demonstrating the harmonious blending of periods and styles. HARTH-MIDDLETON HOUSE, 68 South Battery, c. 1797. Originally built by John Harth as a typical Adam style single house. In 1843 Henry Augustus Middleton, of Weehaw, enlarged it and the grounds, which now stand on land once occupied by bustling lumber yards and marsh. Noteworthy for garden, now the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Batson L. Hewitt. TOUR B Sunday, March 23'2 p.m. to 6 p.m. 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., March 17, 18, 19, 20, 21. 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., March 24, 25, 26, 27, 28. ELIHU HALL BAY, 76 Meeting Street, c. 1785. (Note'Open only week of March 17 through 21.) A house of dignified simplicity showing the style which immediately followed the Revolution, when Judge Bay built for comfort and efficiency this completely developed Charleston "single" house, one of the first with three stories. Now the rectory of St. Michael's Church, it is furnished with much fine furniture and many memorabilia of Commodore M. C. Perry's first expedition to Japan. Home of the Reverend and Mrs. DeWolf Perry. COLONEL WILLIAM RHETT'S HOUSE, 54 Hasell Street, c. 1712. (Note- Open only week of March 24 through 28.) Believed to be oldest house in Charleston, built in reign of Queen Anne by William Rhett, Vice-Admiral of the Province who cleared its coasts of pirates. Birthplace of Wade Hampton, commander of Confederate cavalry, and great governor of South Carolina. Distinguished for unusual Georgian plaster ornaments, exquisite woodwork and furnishings. Home of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Kittredge, Jr. JOSEPH WINTHROP'S HOUSE, 129 Tradd Street, c. 1797. Restrained Adam style of principal rooms practically in original condition, built by Joseph Winthrop, of New England, who married a sister of Charles Fraser, the miniaturist. Residence of Admiral and Mrs. William S. Popham. WILLIAM GIBBES' HOUSE, 64 South Battery, c. 1772. Splendid Georgian mansion, built by William Gibbes at the water side. Has had such owners as the Ret. John Grimke Drayton, who planted the Magnolia Gardens, and the late Mrs. Washington A. Roebling, widow of the builder of the Brooklyn Bridge, who restored house and garden. Home of Mr. and Mrs. John Ashby Farrow. Noted for wonderful furniture, magnificent ballroom. ASHLEY HALL, 172 Rutledge Avenue, c. 1816. Massive Regency house, noted for its spiralling stairway, ornate woodwork and mantels. Once the home of George A. Trenholm, great Charleston merchant and Secretary of the Treasury of the Confederate States. Since 1909 it has been a famous Southern School for girls. TOUR C WILLIAM GIBBES' HOUSE CHARLESTON'S HISTORIC HOUSES [arch 16 to April 12,1952 Special feature for 1952, Sunday afternoon Tours on Sunday, March 16, March 23, March 30 and April 6. No tour on Easter Sunday. No Historic Charleston Foundation Tours on Saturday. Sunday, March 30'2 p.m. to 6 p.m. 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., March 31, April 1, 2, 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., April 7, 8, 9, 10, 11. 3, 4. WILLIAM GIBBES' HOUSE, 64 South Battery, c. 1772. (Note: This house will be on Tour C, the first week in April and on Tour D, the second week in April, from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., alternating with Mrs. William Heyward's House, 31 Legare Street.) Splendid Georgian mansion, built by William Gitibes at the water side. Has had such owners as the Rev. John Grimke Drayton, who planted the Magnolia Gardens, and the late Mrs. Washington A. Roebling, widow of the builder of the Brooklyn Bridge, who restored house and gardens. Home of Mr. and Mrs. John Ashby Farrow. Noted for wonderful furniture, magnificent ballroom. PHILIP PORCHER'S HOUSE, 19 Archdale Street, c. 1765. With its high brick basement and back and front steps, house reminiscent of old plantation homes. Built by Philip Porcher, who made a fortune planting Indigo. Little changed, it has just come back to the builder's family, and the owners, Mr. and Mrs. Richard G. White, have furnished it with many family pieces. MRS. JANE WIGHTMAN'S HOUSE, 36 Chalmers Street, c. 1840. Built early in the Greek Revival style. Remodelled as a residence by Miss Josephine Pinckney, the Charleston author. Notable for its handsome and historic furnishings from the family plantations of El Dorado and Fairfield. ASHLEY HALL, 172 Rutledge Avenue, c. 1816. Massive Regency house, notable for spiralling stairway, ornate woodwork and mantels. Once home of George A. Trenholm, great Charleston merchant and Secretary of the Treasury of the Confederate States. Since 1909 a famous Southern School for girls. TOUR 0 ASHLEY HALL Sunday, April 6'2 p. m. to 6 p.m. 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., March 31, April 1, 2, 10 a.m. to 1 p.m., April 7, 8, 9, 10, 11. MRS. WILLIAM HEYWARD'S HOUSE, 31 Legare Street, c. 1789 (Note: This house will be on Tour D the first week in April, and on Tour C the second week in April from 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., alternating with the William Gibbes House, 64 South Battery.) Built by Hannah Shubrick Heyward, member of one of greatest rice-planting families of the Low Country. Fine panelling and delicate Adam ornament, particularly noteworthy drawing room with half-round bay and palladian window. One of Charleston's haunted houses. Home of Mr. and Mrs. A. T. Smythe. GEORGE EVELEIGH'S HOUSE, 39 Church Street, c. 1733. Built by Eveleigh, whose great Indian trade went as far west as the Mississippi. Its street was a creek when it was built. Long the home of Miss Mary 0. Marshall and her family. Most of the furniture of Charleston origin, and for generations in owner's family. THOMAS LEGARE'S HOUSE, 90 Church Street, c. 1760. Built in handsome mid-Georgian style by well-known Huguenot when Church Street was lively part of Charleston's business district. Home of Mr. W. Lucas Simons. Typical piazza, overlooking garden with arched brick walls, makes charming entrance to house filled with family furniture and portraits. COLONEL OTHNIEL BEALE'S HOUSE, 101 East Bay Street, c. 1740. Othniel Beale, immigrant from New England, Colonel of provincial troops in charge of strengthening the town's fortifications, built on this property just after the great fire of 1740. Handsome rooms, panelled with Low Country cypress, show how merchant of Charleston once lived. Home of Mr. and Mrs. Lionel K. Legge. COLONEL OTHNIEL BEALE'S HOUSE GEORGE EVELEIGH'S HOUSE THOMAS LEGARE'S HOUSE SPECIAL EVENING TOURS Tuesday and Thursday Evenings TIMOTHY FORD'S HOUSE Tuesday Evenings, 8 p.m. to 10 p.m., March 18, 25, April 1 and 8. JAMES SHOOLBRED'S HOUSE, 2 Ladson Street, e. 1793. James Shoolbred, first British consul at Charleston, probably built this house when he married Mary, daughter and heiress of Thomas Middleton of Crowfieid. Unusual woodwork with fine overmantels. Home of Mr. and Mrs. B. Owen Geer, who have filled its fine rooms with many handsome things. Thursday Evenings, 8 p.m. to 10 p.m., March 20, 27, April 3 and 10. TIMOTHY FORD'S HOUSE, 54 Meeting Street, c. 1800. This very handsome house in the Adam style was built by Timothy Ford. According to tradition, Lafayette was entertained here. Residence of Dr. and Mrs. Ransom S. Hooker, who will show the lovely rooms and fine old furniture by candlelight. The Historic Charleston Foundation Historic Charleston Foundation, a non-profit, educational institution, seeks to preserve and use the architectural and historic treasures of the Charleston area'not as museums, but as living parts of the community. With funds from gifts (which are tax free), bequests, and the operation of tours, the Foundation offers planning and financial aid to preserve Charleston's heritage. For, more than any other city in this country, Charleston is a living history of herself. As such she is a national heritage, with street upon street of buildings that serve today as they served the past generations, buildings loved for their beauty, their dignity and comfort, and cherished for their fame. Now through these tours many of these buildings are open to the visitor for the first time. TOURS HEADQUARTERS AND TOURIST INFORMATION BUREAU 94 Church Street Charleston, S. C. Tee. 3-1168 Historic Charleston Foundation maintains a Tourist Information Bureau and Tours Headquarters at 94 Church Street. Here tickets may be purchased and full information secured on Charleston and its environs. Tickets are also on sale at local hotels. ROOMS IN PRIVATE HOMES May be obtained through this office. We advise that reservations be made in advance. HOTELS, INNS AND MOTOR COURTS St. John Hotel'Single, $3.50 to $5; Double, $5 to $10. Brewton Inn'Single, $5; Double, $6 up. Fort Sumter Hotel'Single, $6 to $8; Double $8 to $14. Francis Marion Hotel'Single, $5 up; Double, $8 up. Brookgreen Meadows Court'Double, $8. Lord Ashley Motor Court'-Single, $5; Double, $7 up. Old Town Motor Court'Double, $7.00 up. Sword Gate Lodge Motor Court'Single, $5 up; Double, $6 up. Travelodge Motor Court'Double, $5.50 up. The Wayne Motor Court'Single, $5 up; Double, $6 up. The Pines Motor Court'Double, $6 up. Courtesy Information VIRGINIA AND MARYLAND TOURS: Historic Garden Week in Virginia, April 26-May 3. Headquarters: Room 3, Jefferson Hotel, Richmond 19, Va. Maryland House and Garden Pilgrimage, May 2-11. Headquarters: 217 Sheraton-Belvedere Hotel, Baltimore 2, Maryland. CHARLESTON: Saturday, March 15, 2:00 p.m.'Tour of Town Houses, St. Philip's Woman's Auxiliary. Saturday, March 22, 2:30 p.m'Tour of Town Houses, Women of St. Michael's Church. Saturday, March 29, 10:00 a.m.'Plantation Tour, St. Philip's Women's Auxiliary. Saturday, April 5, 2:00 p.m.'Plantation Tour, Women of St. Michael's Church. Saturday, April 12, 3-6 p.m. and 7-10 p.m.'Tour of Town Houses, Garden Club of Charleston. Wednesday and Friday Evenings, March 26-28, April 2-4, 8:00 p.m. Candlelight Concerts at Heyward-Washington House. FOR SCHEDULE SEE INSIDE CENTER SPREAD HISTORIC CHARLESTON NOW IS OPENING HER GATES AND DOORS Charlestonians are now welcoming the public to some of their finest homes. When spring is at its height and the famous gardens are in bloom, owners of eighteen distinguished houses will show them for the benefit of this historic city, to preserve its beauty and its interest for the nation, through TOURS OF HISTORIC HOUSES Fifth Annual Series of Tours Through Private Homes Sponsored by Historic Charleston Foundation MARCH 16 TO APRIL 12, 1952 There will be a series of four tours, with four houses on each tour. Each day, Monday through Friday, there will be a morning and an afternoon tour; each Sunday, with the exception of Easter, an afternoon tour. Houses will be shown by candlelight on Tuesday and Thursday evenings. TOURS ALTERNATE The first two tours, A and B, will be shown March 16 through March 28, and eight homes will be open. The second two tours, C and D, will be shown March 30 through April 11 and eight other houses will be open. The hours are 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. each morning, and 3 p.m. to 6 p.m., each afternoon. On Sundays the hours are 2 p.m. to 6 p.m. Houses are open in the evenings from 8 to 10 p.m. No homes are open on Saturday. Trained Hostesses On Hand Visitors are conducted through the homes by hostesses. Homes may be visited in any order desired. A tour ticket is good for the entire two week period and entitles the visitor to one admission to each house at any time during the hours the house is open. Transportation when desired will be available at reasonable cost. TARIFF DAYTIME TOURS (A, B, C, D): Fee for each tour $3.50. Fee for combination of A and B, or C and D, $5.50. Special Evening Tours: One house only. Fee: $1. For Schedule, See Inside Center Spread. For further Information write: Historic Charleston Foundation, 94 Church Street, Charleston, S. C.
